case_name: Jagdish Prasad v. District Magistrate, Ranchi

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 1972 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for writ in nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 1972 of 1973. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the issue of Writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner detained by order of the District Magistrate for anti-social proclivity prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner detained by the order of the District Magistrate for anti-social proclivity prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity challenges its validity in this petition for habeas companypus.

facts.text: Detention order No. 1182/C dated 9th October, 1973 issued by District Magistrate, Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the admitted facts and the authoritative law and their interaction. It is best to begin with the impugned order itself which reads No. 1182/C dated, the 9th October, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner is Shri Jagdish Prasad, Proprietor M/s Lachmi Bhandar, North Market Road, Upper Bazar, Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas I am satisfied that with a view to preventing Shri Jagdish Prasad, Proprietor M s Lachmi Bhandar, North Market Road, Upper Bazar, Ranchi, from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity,

facts.text: Detention under Sub-section (2) of Section 3 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 (No. 26 of 1971).

anchor.surface_text: Now, therefore, in exercise of the powers companyferred by Sub-section  2  of the Section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  No. 26 of 1971 , 1 hereby direct that the said Shri Jagdish Prasad be detained.

facts.text: Petitioner to be detained in Ranchi Jail, classified as Class Y and division IB.

anchor.surface_text: He shall be treated in detention in Ranchi Jail and classified as Class Y and in division IB. N. Sinha  District Magistrate, Ran-.hi.

facts.text: On 2-10-72 at about 12 O'Clock at night, petitioner transporting 50 bags of rice on truck No. BRV 6627 checked by Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Sadar, Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: That you on 2-10-72 at about 12 OClock at night were transporting 50 bags of rice weighing on truck No. BRV 6627 which was checked by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Sadar, Ranchi.

facts.text: Petitioner produced cash memo book asserting 15 bags sold to Biswanath Flour Mill, Khelari; 10 bags to Pramod Flour Mill, Khelari; 10 bags to Shri Kundanlal, Khelari.

anchor.surface_text: That you produced at the time of checking cash memo book and you asserted that out of 50 bags of rice seized oil the said truck, 15 bags of rice were sold to Biswanath Floor Mill, Khelari, 10 bags of rice to Pramod Floor Mill, Khelari and 10 bags to Shri Kundanlal Khelari.

facts.text: Cash memo No. 1134 dated 2-10-73 showed sale of 15 bags to M/s Biswanath Flour Mill, Khelari, licence number 34/69 R.

anchor.surface_text: That in support of your assertion as stated in Para No. 2 above, you produced Cash memo No. 1134 dated 2-10-73 showing sale of 15 bags of rice to M s Biswanath Flour Mill, Khelari and you mentioned licence Number of M s Biswanath Flour as 34/69  R

facts.text: Verification by Magistrate 1st Class, Ranchi at Khelari: Biswanath Flour Mill licence is 63/68, not 34/69; proprietor Jagi Ram did not purchase rice on 2-10-73.

anchor.surface_text: On verification by a Magistrate 1st Class, Ranchi, at Khelari from Shri Jagi Ram, Proprietor of M s Biswanath Flour Mill, Khelari, it has been established that the licence number of the firm is 63/68 and number 34/69. Shri Jagi Ram has also asserted that he did number purchase any rice from you or from any other place on 2-10-73.

facts.text: Cash memo No. 1135 dated 2-10-73 showed sale of 10 bags to M/s Pramod Flour Mill, Khelari, licence 31/68 R.

anchor.surface_text: That similarly in support of assertion as stated in Para 2 above, you produced Cash memo No. 1135 dated 2-10-73 showing sale of 10 bags of rice to M s Pramod Flour Mill of Khelari showing their licence number as 31/68  R .

facts.text: Verification: Pramod Flour Mill licence is 9/72, not 31/69; no licence in 1969; no purchase on 2-10-73.

anchor.surface_text: On ac- tual verification at Khalari by a Magistrate 1st Class, Ranchi, from Shri Bhagwan Singh, Proprietor of M s Pramod Flour Mill, Khelari it has been established that the licence of M s Pramod Flour Mill, Khelari is 9/72 and number 31/69. It has also been established that M s Pramod Flour Mill, Khelari had numberlicense in 1969. It has also been established that on 2-10-73 M s Flour Mill Khelari did number make any purchase of rice from you or from any other shop.

facts.text: Cash memo No. 1137 dated 2-10-73 showed sale of 10 bags to Shri Kundan Lal, Khelari, licence 26/67 R.

anchor.surface_text: That similarly in support of your assertion as stated in Para No. 2 above, you produced cash memo No. 1137 dated 2-10-73 showing sale of 10 bags of rice. to Shri Kundan Lal of Khelari showing his licence number as 26/67 R .

facts.text: Verification: Kundan Lal has no foodgrain dealers licence, does not deal in foodgrains; no purchase on 2-10-73.

anchor.surface_text: On actual verification at Khelari by a Magistrate 1st Class, Ranchi, from Shri Kundan Lal of Khelari it has been estab- lished that Shri Kundan Lal of Khelari has got numberfoodgrain dealers licence, number he deals in foodgrains. It has also been established that the said Kundan Lal of Khelari did number purchase any rice from you on 2-10-73.

facts.text: Petitioner is a licensed wholesale dealer.

anchor.surface_text: Even the admitted facts are tell-tale. The petitioner is a licensed wholesale dealer.

facts.text: Petitioner's licence restricts business to specified place, no transport and sale outside premises.

anchor.surface_text: He can carry on his business only at a place mentioned in his licence and number do transport and sale outside those premises.

facts.text: Petitioner can sell only to wholesale or retail merchant holding a permit.

anchor.surface_text: He can sell only to a wholesale or retail merchant holding a per- mit.

facts.text: Petitioner must issue correct receipt with customer name, address, licence number and keep duplicate.

anchor.surface_text: He shall issue to every customer a companyrect receipt giving the name, address and licence number of the customer and other details and keep a duplicate of the same.

facts.text: Court finds petitioner's actions violate licence conditions.

anchor.surface_text: On the recitals in the annexure to the order, the petitioner has, in violation of all these safeguards, attempted to run the gauntlet of the law.

facts.text: District Magistrate satisfied detention necessary to prevent activities prejudicial to supplies and services.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances I am satisfied that it he is allowed to remain at large, he will indulge in activities prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity for prevention of such activities I companysider his detention necessary.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KRISHNA IYER, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by. KRISHNA IYER, J.

anchor.surface_text: Frank Anthony and S. K. Gambhir, for the petitioner. K. Sinha and S. K. Sinha, for the respondents.

issues.text: Whether the detention order suffers from a fatal defect due to uncertainty in specifying whether the detention is to prevent acts prejudicial to maintenance of supplies or services essential to the community

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner detained by the order of the District Magistrate for anti-social proclivity prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community challenges its validity in this petition for habeas corpus. Mr. Frank Anthony has vigorously urged two vital defects as vitiating the detention order incarcerating the petitioner, based mainly on the, unreported ruling of this Court in Prabhu Dayal v. District Magistrate, Kamrup 1 , the well- known Lohia 2  case and a few other peripheral W. P. No. 1496 of 1973 judgment dated October 11, 1973. A. I. R. 1960 S. C. 633. observations in other decisions. The District Magistrate was uncertain whether he would detain the petitioner to prevent disruption of maintenance of supplies or of services essential to the life of the community and such a mindless order suffered from a fatal genetic disease diagnosed by this Court in many decisions as fatal, runs the submission.

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are vague or lacking in particulars, particularly with respect to disruption of services, rendering the entire detention order invalid
Whether blackmarketing and illicit transport of rice constitutes activity prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community

anchor.surface_text: No Doubt blackmarketing has at its base a shortening of supplies because blackmarket flourishes best when the availability of commodities is rendered difficult. It has a definite tendency to disrupt supplies when scarcity exists or scarcity is created artificially by hoarding to attain illegitimate profits. Indulging in blackmarketing is conduct which is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies. It is hardly necessary to read supplies conjunctively with services, as was contended although cases may exist where supplies and services may both be affected.

issues.text: Whether the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority is based on relevant material and rational forecast, justifying the preventive detention

anchor.surface_text: Section 36 3  of the Defence of India Rules, 1971 defines it to mean essential commodity means food, water, fuel, light, power or any other thing essential for the existence of the community... In the circumstances I am satisfied that it he is allowed to remain at large, he will indulge in activities prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community for prevention of such activities I consider his detention necessary.

issues.text: Whether the detention complies with the procedure established by law under Article 21, safeguarding personal liberty

arguments.claim: Detention order vitiated by fatal defect due to District Magistrate's uncertainty whether detention to prevent disruption of supplies or services essential to community

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Frank Anthony has vigorously urged two vital defects as vitiating the detention order incarcerating the petitioner, based mainly on the, unreported ruling of this Court in Prabhu Dayal v. District Magistrate, Kamrup 1 , the well- known Lohia 2  case and a few other peripheral W. P. No. 1496 of 1973 judgment dated October 11, 1973. A. I. R. 1960 S. C. 633. observations in other decisions. The District Magistrate was uncertain whether he would detain the petitioner to prevent disruption of maintenance of supplies or of services essential to the life of the community and such a mindless order suffered from a fatal genetic disease diagnosed by this Court in many decisions as fatal, runs the submission.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cted here with a little readjustment. Similies and metaphors land literary grace to legal argument but are apt to play tricks in areas of strict logic

arguments.court_reasoning: Supplies and services not strictly conjunctive; blackmarketing disrupts supplies and contextually affects both; overlap in essential commodities like food.

arguments.claim: Semantics of 'supplies and services' shows blackmarketing affects supplies only, not services

anchor.surface_text: The semantics of supplies and services in this context, argued Sri Anthony, serves to show that certain activities bear upon supplies only, e.g., hoarding or blackmarketing, while other actings may disrupt services only , e.g., sabotage of railway tracks or scavengers strike. He argued that some misconduct may be ambidextral as for example, huge quantities of telegraph wires being poached or a railway wagon being looted in an organised manner. The cornerstone of his contention, in the first stage, is that blackmarketing in foodgrains belongs to the first species- essential supplies-and not to the second- essential services

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cted here with a little readjustment. Similies and metaphors land literary grace to legal argument but are apt to play tricks in areas of strict logic

arguments.court_reasoning: Rameshwar Lal holds blackmarketing prejudicial to supplies; not necessary to read conjunctively; word 'and' used disjunctively.

arguments.claim: Grounds of detention vague and lacking particulars especially regarding disruption of services, rendering entire order invalid even if supplies ground good

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that the particulars furnished relate to supplies only and how services are affected is left vague. If one ground is vague, the order fails. In Rameshwar Lal 1  it was pointed out where some grounds are found to be non are cancelled or given up, the detention cannot be justified if the grounds are not sufficiently precise and do not furnish details for the purpose of making effective representation the detention can be questioned. In this connection, Shri Anthony forcefully urged his case that services being disrupted was one of the precise reasons for the detention, but no particulars which would make out that ground, apart from the distinct ground of preventing supplies, have been given. On the reasoning in Prabhu Dayal the order is illegal, he argued.

arguments.court_reasoning: Grounds provide prolix particulars of midnight rice transport, fake cash memos, verifications showing no purchases/licenses; rational basis for prejudicial activity to supplies/services.

arguments.claim: Affidavit shows mental vacillation of detaining authority by striking off 'and services' after 'supplies'

anchor.surface_text: Shri Anthony relied on the mental vacillation of the detaining officer as disclosed in the affidavit in return filed by the State where and services is struck off after maintenance of supplies. If this reflects the slippery satisfaction of the District Magistrate it is unfortunate.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Since the detenu is number placed before a Magistrate and has only a right of being supplied the grounds of detention with a view to his making a repr

arguments.court_reasoning: Affidavit sloppy and by junior without knowledge; but not material as detention order grounds admitted and cumulative, not alternative.

arguments.claim: Blackmarketing prejudicial to maintenance of supplies

anchor.surface_text: In Rameshwar Lal v. State of Bihar 1  this Court pointed out No doubt blackmarketing has at its base a shortening of supplies because blackmarket flourishes best when the availability of commodities is rendered difficult. It has a definite tendency to disrupt supplies when scarcity exists or scarcity is created artificially by hoarding to attain illegitimate profits. Indulging in blackmarketing is conduct which is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies.

arguments.claim: 'Supplies and services' to be read disjunctively, not conjunctively

anchor.surface_text: It is hardly necessary to read supplies conjunctively with services, as was contended although cases may exist where supplies and services may both be affected. The word and is not used conjunctively but disjunctively.

arguments.claim: Concentric circles analogy from Lohia inappropriate for supplies/services context

anchor.surface_text: The familiar imagery in Lohias case of concentric circles in the context of Law and Order  the larger circle  and public order  the smaller but graver one  was projected here with a little readjustment. Similies and metaphors lend literary grace to legal argument but are apt to play tricks in areas of strict logic or codified law. Courts have to be cautious while transplanting picturesque projections from one situation to another.

arguments.claim: Essential commodities like food, light, power are both supplies and services

anchor.surface_text: For example, an essential commodity is at once a supply and a service. Section 36 3  of the Defence of India Rules, 1971 defines it to mean essential commodity means food, water, fuel, light, power or any other thing essential for the existence of the community which is notified in this behalf by Government Light and power thus are commodities so also food and water. Yet who will deny that light is a service or drinking water, for that matter ?

arguments.claim: Illicit transport of rice affects both supplies and services essential to community

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in the dichotomy between the two attempted by counsel in the special context of a State being called upon in. an emergency to supply that primary necessity of existence, viz., food, which is perhaps the basic service which Government must render to the people. In the present case, the allegation is of nocturnal, illegal, rice transport, intercepted by officials, and you do no violence to language to describe that activity as prejudicial to supplies and services.

arguments.claim: Grounds of detention precise and detailed, providing real opportunity for representation; not vague

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of section 8 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  No. 26 of 1971 , Shri Jagdish Prasad, Proprietor M s Lachmi Bhandar, North Market Road, Upper Bazar, Ranchi is informed that he has been ordered to be de- tained in my order No. 1182/C dated 9th October, 73 on the following grounds - That you on 2-10-72 at about 12 OClock at night were transporting 50 bags of rice weighing on truck No. BRV 6627 which was checked by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Sadar, Ranchi.

arguments.claim: Detaining authority's subjective satisfaction rational based on detailed material of license violations and blackmarketing
Preventive detention justified by intelligent forecast of future prejudicial acts from past conduct
Procedure established by law rigorously observed; personal liberty protected
Detention order valid under subjective satisfaction of District Magistrate per MISA s3(2)

anchor.surface_text: Now, the admitted facts and the authoritative law and their interaction. It is best to begin with the impugned order itself which reads No. 1182/C dated, the 9th October, 1973. Whereas I am satisfied that with a view to preventing Shri Jagdish Prasad, Proprietor M s Lachmi Bhandar, North Market Road, Upper Bazar, Ranchi, from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community, it is necessary to make an order that he be de- tained.

arguments.court_reasoning: Material supports rational satisfaction; no vagueness.

holdings.text: The phrase 'maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community' is to be read disjunctively, not conjunctively.

anchor.surface_text: It is hardly necessary to read supplies conjunctively with services, as was contended although cases may exist where supplies and services may both be affected. The word and is not used conjunctively but disjunctively. If sweepers strike, noquestion of disrupting sup-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'and' as disjunctive; blackmarketing disrupts supplies primarily but essential commodities like food blur distinction between supplies and services.

holdings.text: Blackmarketing and illicit nocturnal transport of rice by a licensed dealer in violation of licence conditions constitutes acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in the dichotomy between the two attempted by counsel in the special context of a State being called upon in. an emergency to supply that primary necessity of existence, viz., food, which is perhaps the basic service which Government must render to the people. In the present case, the allegation is of nocturnal, illegal, rice transport, intercepted by officials, and you do no violence to language to describe that activity as prejudicial to supplies and services.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of precedent from Rameshwar Lal; food is both supply and service; specific facts of midnight transport and fake memos show prejudice to distribution control.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention are not vague or lacking in particulars; they provide prolix details of specific incidents enabling effective representation.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of section 8 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 No. 26 of 1971 , Shri Jagdish Prasad, Proprietor M s Lachmi Bhandar, North Market Road, Upper Bazar, Ranchi is informed that he has been ordered to be de- tained in my order No. 1182/C dated 9th October, 73 on the following grounds - That you on 2-10-72 at about 12 OClock at night were transporting 50 bags of rice weighing on truck No. BRV 6627 which was checked by the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Sadar, Ranchi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed narration of truck check, fake cash memos, verifications disproving claims; distinguishes Prabhu Dayal and Keshav Talpade where grounds lacked basis or details.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate's subjective satisfaction is genuine, rational and based on relevant material warranting preventive detention.

anchor.surface_text: Even the admitted facts are tell-tale. The petitioner is a licensed wholesale dealer. He can carry on his business only at a place mentioned in his licence and not do transport and sale outside those premises. He can sell only to a wholesale or retail merchant holding a per- mit. He shall issue to every customer a correct receipt giving the name, address and licence number of the customer and other details and keep a duplicate of the same. On the recitals in the annexure to the order, the petitioner has, in violation of all these safeguards, attempted to run the gauntlet of the law. An intelligent forecast made by the District Magistrate that the detenu would break the control system and blackmarket in rice cannot be castigated as irrational.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Past violations of licence (transport outside premises, fake memos to unlicensed) provide basis for forecast of future prejudicial acts; preventive not punitive.

holdings.text: The detention order complies with the procedure established by law under Article 21; personal liberty not invaded invalidly.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure rigorously observed here with precise grounds under s.8 MISA; no vagueness or irrelevance; emphasizes strict compliance as bastion of liberty.

holdings.text: The detention order is valid; writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Anyway, we cannot hold the order bad, in economics or law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above holdings; material supports order under MISA s.3(2).

holdings.text: Mechanical affidavits by junior officials without personal knowledge are not satisfactory in habeas corpus returns.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Anthony relied on the mental vacillation of the detaining officer as disclosed in the affidavit in return filed by the State where and services is struck off after maintenance of supplies. If this reflects the slippery satisfaction of the District Magistrate it is unfortunate. Here some Upper Division Assistant , Special , Home Department, has sworn an affidavit, not with personal knowledge but with paper wisdom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Probative requirement demands affidavit from detaining authority or senior officer; sloppy affidavits undermine process though not fatal here.

The District Magistrate was uncertain whether he would detain the petitioner to prevent disruption of maintenance of supplies or of services essential to the life of the companymunity and such a mindless order suffered from a fatal genetic disease diagnosed by this Court in many decisions as fatal, runs the submission.

It has a definite tendency to disrupt supplies when scarcity exists or scarcity is created artificially by hoarding to attain illegitimate profits. Indulging in blackmarketing is companyduct which is prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies. precedents.cited_holding: No doubt blackmarketing has at its base a shortening of supplies [...] The word and is not used conjunctively but disjunctively.

anchor.surface_text: In Blackpool Corporation v. Lovkar 1  it was held that providing housing accommodation fell within the scope of supplies and services in Regulation 51  1  of the Defence  General  Regulation, 1939. We see numberforce in the dichotomy between the two attempted by companynsel in the special companytext of a State being called upon in. an emergency to supply that primary necessity of existence, viz., food, which is perhaps the basic service which Government must render to the people.

precedents.cited_proposition: providing housing accommodation fell within supplies and services
precedents.cited_holding: providing housing accommodation fell within the scope of supplies and services in Regulation 51(1) of the Defence (General) Regulation, 1939

anchor.surface_text: Rameshwar Lal 1  elicited some stern observations from Hidayatullah, J., as he then was. The learned Judge said However, the detention of a person without a trial, merely on the subjective satisfaction of an authority however high, is a serious matter. It must require the closest scrutiny of the material on which the decision is formed, leaving numberroom for errors or at least avoidable errors.

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar Lal v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: detention requires closest scrutiny; grounds must not be vague to allow effective representation
precedents.cited_holding: the grounds must not be vague or indefinite and must afford a real opportunity to make a representation against the detention

precedents.citation: Keshav Talpade v. Emperor 2 [...] A.I.R. 1943 F.C.R.1,8. 375.

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made in the above case by the learned Judge to Keshav Talpade v. Emperor 2  where it was said If a detaining authority gave four reasons for detaining a man, without distinguishing between them, and any two or three of the reasons are held to be bad, it can never be certain to what extent the bad reasons operated on the mind of the authority or whether the detention order would have been made at all if only one or two good reasons had been before them.

precedents.cited_proposition: if some grounds for detention are bad, cannot be certain detention would have been made on remaining good grounds alone
precedents.cited_holding: if a detaining authority gave four reasons [...] it can never be certain [...] whether the detention order would have been made at all if only one or two good reasons had been before them

anchor.surface_text: If one ground is vague, the order fails. In Rameshwar Lal 1  it was pointed out where some grounds are found to be number are cancelled or given up, the detention cannot be justified if the grounds are number sufficiently precise and do number furnish details for the purpose of making effective representation the detention can be questioned.

precedents.case_name: Rameshwar Lal v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: if some grounds are vague, imprecise or abandoned, detention cannot be justified
precedents.cited_holding: where some grounds are found to be non-existing or are cancelled or given up, the detention cannot be justified if the grounds are not sufficiently precise

Anyway, we cannot hold the order bad, in economics or law.

anchor.surface_text: Even the admitted facts are tell-tale. The petitioner is a licensed wholesale dealer. He can carry on his business only at a place mentioned in his licence and not do transport and sale outside those premises. He can sell only to a wholesale or retail merchant holding a per- mit. He shall issue to every customer a correct receipt giving the name, address and licence number of the customer and other details and keep a duplicate of the same. On the recitals in the annexure to the order, the petitioner has, in violation of all these safeguards, attempted to run the gauntlet of the law. An intelligent forecast made by the District Magistrate that the detenu would break the control system and blackmarket in rice cannot be castigated as irrational.
Anyway, we cannot hold the order bad, in economics or law.
